results.title: Moments of the runner
results.creator_credit: Marlin Darrah, Marlin Darrah Films and Runners World Magazine
results.brief_description: Examines five of America’s most popular long-distance running competitions: Boston, New York, Chicage, Eugene and the Bay to Breakers. Includes a historical overview with scenes of Moscow, Greece, San Francisco and describes the diversity of people who take up running.

results.title: Moments in music
results.creator_credit: Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences
results.brief_description: Illustrates the range of musical talent to be found in feature motion pictures; Lily Pons, Betty Hutton, Nelson Eddy and Jeanette MacDonald, Red Skelton and Betty Garrett, Leopold Stowoski, Xavier Cugat, Rise Stevens, Bing Crosby, Harry James, Judy Garland. “All this”, the film concludes, “is brilliantly yours, at your neighbourhood theatre, when you go to the movies”.

results.title: Moment of brightness
results.creator_credit: Peter Drummond, Beaumaris Film Productions and Victorian Secondary Teachers' Association
results.brief_description: A Victorian high school teacher, Gil Freeman, tells of the problems in his present school - a typically old, poor, overcrowded, ill-equipped metropolitan high school, and his approach to teaching in this environment. He finds that teaching higher forms is only a form of cramming necessary for entrance to university or college; with younger forms he has the opportunity to experiment and acknowledge each child’s individuality. Also tells of his own background, and includes a meeting of a teachers’ association. Commentary by Bill Hannah

results.title: Molly & Moborak = Molly and Moborak [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Tom Zubrycki, Film Finance Corporation Australia and Jotz Productions
results.brief_description: This moving, understated work focuses on the mixed fortunes of an Afghanistan refugee, Mobarak Tahiri, who finds work and an adopted family in the small town of Young, New South Wales. Along with many of his fellow refugees, Mobarak works in the local abattoir, receiving praise for their work ethic. Local community members show great support for the refugees - organising English lessons, soccer matches and outings. But despite this goodwill, at times the town seethes with racial hatred and bigotry. Set against the backdrop of Prime Minister John Howard’s hard-line stance on asylum seekers, “Molly & Mobarak” depicts friendship, kindness, romance and tolerance. Veteran Australian filmmaker Tom Zubrycki’s sympathies clearly lie with the asylum seekers, but this does not prevent the work from being intelligent and thought provoking.

results.title: Molecules at work (TEFC)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Laws of Disorder Series”.
Shows that most of the energy that is used by man is derived from chemical re-actions. Illustrates how chemical energy is converted to heat and how the heat is converted into work as efficiently as possible. Professor Sir George Porter is the lecturer and author of the series.

results.title: Molecules and life
results.creator_credit: Peter De Normanville, Anvil Films and Educational Foundation for Visual Aids
results.brief_description: Outlines achievements in molecular biology which have revolutionised our understanding of the chemical and physical basis of life. Includes the structure of large organic molecules such as insulin, haemoglobin, myoglobin and vitamin B12, the joining together of amino acids, the complexity of proteins, x-ray crystallography, and clinical applications of scientists’ work.

results.title: Molds and how they grow
results.brief_description: Laboratory demonstrations show the effects of moisture and temperature on the growth of moulds. Photomicrography reveals the structure of moulds hyphae, mycelium, sporeballs, spores. Beginning with spores on a rice culture, timelapse photography shows the formation of a new colony.

results.title: Modern Wales
results.creator_credit: Peter Hopkinson, James Carr and World Wide Pictures
results.brief_description: The fluctuating world demand for the wealth which lay beneath the lovely valleys of Wales - her iron, steel and coal - brought severe economic depression. As a consequence, Welsh industry was re-orientated so that it would never again rely on a few basic products.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Peter Hopkinson, James Carr and World Wide Pictures
